questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with hypertension and hypokalemia. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs). Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with her symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Conn syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Liddle syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism (GRA)

options.label: D
options.text: Secondary hyperaldosteronism

questions.explanation:
Feature

Primary Hyperaldosteronism (Option A)

Secondary Hyperaldosteronism (Option D)

Cause

Adrenal gland disorders

High plasma renin activity conditions

Examples

Adenomas, adrenal hyperplasia, carcinoma, Glucocorticoid-Remediable Aldosteronism (Option C)

Cirrhosis, heart failure, nephrosis, salt-losing adrenogenital syndrome

Renin Activity

Suppressed

Elevated

GRA Mechanism

Hybrid gene sensitive to ACTH

Not applicable

ECF Volume

Normal or increased

Decreased

questions.text: Which layer of the adrenal cortex is correctly paired with its primary hormone?

options.label: A
options.text: Zona fasciculata - Androgens

options.label: B
options.text: Zona glomerulosa - Aldosterone

options.label: C
options.text: Zona reticularis - Cortisol

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

questions.explanation:
Layers of Adrenal gland

Adrenal Cortex:

Zones of the cortex

Hormones produced

Main function

Morphology of Zone

Zona Glomerulosa (Option B)

Mineralocorticoid

  • Aldosterone(main)
  • Deoxycorticosterone

Maintenance of sodium balance

Small clumps of cells

Zona fasciculata (Option A)

Glucocorticoids

  • Cortisol
  • Corticosterone

Maintenance of sugars

Columnar cells that form long cords

Zona reticularis (Option C)

Sex steroids

  • Dehydroepiandrosterone
  • Androstenedione

Maintenance of sexual functioning

Network of intercalated cells

Adrenal medulla:

Medulla

Catecholamines:

  • Norepinephrine
  • Epinephrine
  • Small amounts of dopamine
  • Carbohydrate and fat metabolisms
  • Fight or flight responses

Specialized sympathetic ganglion

Clumps and strands of chromaffin cells

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has been on long-term corticosteroid therapy for rheumatoid arthritis. The physician advises tapering the dose gradually rather than stopping it abruptly. What is the reason for this advice?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid the risk of adrenal insufficiency

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid the risk of Cushing's syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent a sudden increase in blood glucose levels

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent sudden increase in blood pressure

questions.correct_answer: A. To avoid the risk of adrenal insufficiency

questions.text: Which among the following statements are true regarding the action of aldosterone to enhance sodium reabsorption at the molecular level in renal cells? (a) Inhibits the excretion of K+ to preserve Na+ (b) Activation of sgk gene (serum and glucocorticoid- regulated kinase) (c) Increases ENaC (Epithelial Na+ Channels) activity (d) Increases activity of Na+-K+ exchanger

options.label: A
options.text: a, b, and c

options.label: B
options.text: a and c

options.label: C
options.text: b, c and d

options.label: D
options.text: c and d

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary physiological trigger for the suppression of aldosterone secretion?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased serum potassium levels

options.label: B
options.text: Expansion of the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume

options.label: C
options.text: Increased renin release

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased blood pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. Expansion of the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume

questions.text: Which of the following describes the mechanism by which glucocorticoids regulate metabolic reactions and ACTH secretion?

options.label: A
options.text: Directly catalyzing metabolic reactions and stimulating ACTH secretion

options.label: B
options.text: Binding to glucocorticoid receptors and acting as transcription factors

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibiting catecholamine action and decreasing mRNA synthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Influence cellular processes by directly altering gene expression.

questions.correct_answer: B. Binding to glucocorticoid receptors and acting as transcription factors
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Production

Adrenal cortex

Mechanism of Action

Bind to receptors, form complexes, act as transcription factors

Nongenomic Actions

Influence cellular processes without affecting gene expression

Permissive Actions

Necessary for calorigenic, lipolytic effects, pressor responses, bronchodilation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes presents with difficulty managing his blood glucose levels. Which of the following effects of glucocorticoids best explains the patient's difficulty in managing his diabetes?

options.label: A
options.text: Glucocorticoids enhance the action of insulin in peripheral tissues

options.label: B
options.text: Glucocorticoids decrease gluconeogenesis in the liver

options.label: C
options.text: Glucocorticoids promote protein anabolism

options.label: D
options.text: Glucocorticoids counteract the effects of insulin in peripheral tissues

questions.correct_answer: D. Glucocorticoids counteract the effects of insulin in peripheral tissues
questions.explanation:
Intermediary Metabolism:

  • Promote protein catabolism. (Option C)
  • Stimulate liver glycogenesis and gluconeogenesis. (Option B)
  • Enhance glucose-6-phosphatase activity.
  • Elevates plasma glucose level.
  • Counteract insulin effects in peripheral tissues, worsening diabetes. (Option A) (Option D)
  • In diabetes, elevate plasma lipid levels and promote ketone body formation. In healthy individuals, insulin secretion counters this effect.

Permissive Action:

  • Essential for actions of other hormones (e.g., glucagon and catecholamines).
  • Necessary for catecholamine-induced lipolysis, pressor responses, and bronchodilation.

Effects on ACTH Secretion:

  • Regulate adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion via negative feedback.

Vascular Reactivity:

  • Maintain blood vessel responsiveness to norepinephrine and epinephrine.
  • Deficiency leads to decreased vascular responsiveness, capillary dilation, increased permeability, and potential vascular collapse.

Water Metabolism:

  • Regulate water balance.
  • Adrenal insufficiency impairs water excretion, increasing water intoxication risk.

Blood Cells and Lymphatic Organs:

  • Decrease eosinophils and basophils.
  • Increase neutrophils, platelets, and red blood cells.
  • Decrease lymphocytes and reduce lymph node and thymus size.

Stress Resistance:

  • Crucial for stress response.
  • Stress induces ACTH secretion, increasing glucocorticoid levels essential for survival.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of hypertension and hypokalemia. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of aldosterone.Which of the following statements is true regarding the enzyme and the zone responsible for producing aldosterone?

options.label: A
options.text: Aldosterone is produced in the zona fasciculata, and the key enzyme involved is 17α-Hydroxylase

options.label: B
options.text: Aldosterone is synthesized from pregnenolone via progesterone in the zona glomerulosa

options.label: C
options.text: In the zona reticularis, pregnenolone is converted to aldosterone by Aldosterone Synthase

options.label: D
options.text: The zona glomerulosa produces aldosterone directly from cholesterol, bypassing pregnenolone and progesterone

questions.correct_answer: B. Aldosterone is synthesized from pregnenolone via progesterone in the zona glomerulosa
questions.explanation:
Zona

Conversion Pathway

Key Enzymes

Steroid Hormones Produced

Zona Glomerulosa

Pregnenolone → Progesterone → Aldosterone

Aldosterone Synthase (P450c11AS)

Aldosterone

Zona Fasciculata

Pregnenolone → Progesterone or 17α-Hydroxypregnenolone

17α-Hydroxylase

Cortisol, Corticosterone

Zona Reticularis

Pregnenolone → 17α-Hydroxypregnenolone

17α-Hydroxylase

DHEA, Androstenedione

Adrenal Cortex Zone

Enzymes Present

Steroid Hormones Produced

Zona Glomerulosa

Aldosterone Synthase (P450c11AS)

Aldosterone (Option A)

(Option B)

Zona Fasciculata

17α-Hydroxylase, others (Option A)

Cortisol, Corticosterone

Zona Reticularis

17α-Hydroxylase, others

DHEA, Androstenedione (Option C)

Zona

Conversion Pathway

Key Enzymes

Steroid Hormones Produced

Zona Glomerulosa

Pregnenolone → Progesterone → Aldosterone

Aldosterone Synthase (P450c11AS)

Aldosterone

Zona Fasciculata

Pregnenolone → Progesterone or 17α-Hydroxypregnenolone

17α-Hydroxylase

Cortisol, Corticosterone

Zona Reticularis

Pregnenolone → 17α-Hydroxypregnenolone

17α-Hydroxylase

DHEA, Androstenedione

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with signs of early virilization and ambiguous genitalia. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ACTH and 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: 11β-hydroxylase deficiency

options.label: B
options.text: 21β-hydroxylase deficiency

options.label: C
options.text: 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency

options.label: D
options.text: 17α-hydroxylase deficiency

questions.explanation:
Enzyme Deficiency

Description

Symptoms/Consequences

Cholesterol desmolase deficiency

Fatal in utero, prevents placental progesterone synthesis.

Death before birth.

Steroidogenic acute regulatory (StAR) protein deficiency

Known as congenital lipoid adrenal hyperplasia. Prevents cholesterol movement into mitochondria.

Low steroid production, female genitalia regardless of genetic sex.

3β-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency

Increases DHEA secretion (weak androgen).

Masculinization in females, hypospadias in males. (Option C)

17α-Hydroxylase deficiency

Caused by mutated CYP17 gene. Prevents sex hormone production.

Female external genitalia, hypertension, hypokalemia due to high 11-deoxycorticosterone. (Option D- not early virilization)

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

Increased 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone secretion.

Virilization, hypertension due to salt and water retention. (Option A)

Enzyme Deficiency

Impact

Symptoms/Consequences

Cholesterol desmolase

Prevents progesterone synthesis.

Fatal in utero.

StAR protein

Prevents cholesterol movement into mitochondria.

Low steroid production, female genitalia regardless of genetic sex.

3β-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase

Increases DHEA.

Masculinization in females, hypospadias in males.

17α-Hydroxylase

Prevents sex hormone production.

Female external genitalia, hypertension, hypokalemia.

11β-Hydroxylase

Increases 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone.

Virilization, hypertension.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman exhibits positive Chvostek's and Trousseau's signs. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased ionized calcium levels due to hyperventilation

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased ionized calcium levels.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased total calcium levels due to chronic kidney diseas

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased total calcium levels due to vitamin D overdose

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency department with symptoms of muscle spasms and difficulty breathing. She has recently been hyperventilating due to anxiety and reports a tingling sensation in her fingers. On examination, she exhibits a positive Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of tetany in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased calcium absorption due to high levels of parathyroid hormone

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased ionized calcium leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells

options.label: C
options.text: Increased protein ionization due to low pH causing more free Ca2+ availability

options.label: D
options.text: Enhanced bone calcium mobilization from decreased parathyroid hormone levels

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased ionized calcium leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcium regulation is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: PTH promotes calcium reabsorption and phosphate absorption in the renal tubules

options.label: B
options.text: PTH directly enhances calcium absorption in the intestines by increasing the expression of calcium-binding proteins

options.label: C
options.text: PTH directly activates osteoclasts, which break down bone tissue and release calcium into the extracellular fluid

options.label: D
options.text: PTH is essential for the conversion of inactive vitamin D to its active form

questions.correct_answer: D. PTH is essential for the conversion of inactive vitamin D to its active form
questions.explanation:
Factor

Description

Effect on Calcium Levels

PTH
  • A hormone secreted by the parathyroid glands in response to low extracellular calcium levels.

Increases

Bone Resorption

(Option C)
  • PTH stimulates osteoblasts, which signal osteoclasts to break down bone tissue, releasing calcium and phosphate into the bloodstream.

Increases

Renal Excretion (Option A)
  • PTH increases calcium reabsorption in the renal tubules, reducing calcium loss through urine.
  • PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption in the kidneys.

Increases

Intestinal Absorption

(Option B)
  • PTH indirectly enhances calcium and phosphate absorption in the intestines.
  • This active form of vitamin D promotes the formation of calbindin, a calcium-binding protein, in intestinal cells.

Increases

Vitamin D
  • While not directly regulated by PTH, vitamin D plays a crucial role in calcium regulation. Vitamin D must be converted to its active form, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, in the kidneys. PTH is essential for this conversion. (Option D)

Increases

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary role of vitamin D in calcium regulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Vitamin D directly stimulates osteoclast activity to release calcium from bones

options.label: B
options.text: Vitamin D enhances calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, reducing its excretion

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D increases the production of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which mobilizes calcium

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D facilitates the intestinal absorption of calcium, increasing its uptake from food

questions.correct_answer: D. Vitamin D facilitates the intestinal absorption of calcium, increasing its uptake from food
questions.explanation:
Action site

Key concepts

Intestines
  • Increases the production of calbindin (calcium-binding protein) in intestinal epithelial cells which increases calcium absorption.

Kidneys
  • Increases calcium and phosphate reabsorption in the renal tubules, reducing their excretion in urine.
  • This effect is relatively weak

Bones
  • Excessive vitamin D can cause bone resorption.
  • Smaller quantities actually promote bone calcification.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the primary mechanism by which calcitonin lowers blood calcium levels?

options.label: A
options.text: Stimulates osteoblast activity to build new bone tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Increases the absorption of calcium in the intestines

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits osteoclast activity to reduce bone resorption

options.label: D
options.text: Enhances the reabsorption of calcium in the kidneys

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibits osteoclast activity to reduce bone resorption
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Action

Action site

Key concepts

Bone
  • Inhibition of Osteoclast Activity by binding to calcitonin receptors on osteoclast (Option A) and (Option C)
  • Decreased release of calcium and phosphate from bone

Kidneys

  • Increased Calcium Excretion (Option D)

  • Reduces the reabsorption of calcium and phosphate in the renal tubules.

Intestine

  • Decreased Calcium Absorption (Minor Role) (Option B)

  • Effect is less compared to kidney

questions.text: Which of the following markers is primarily used to assess bone resorption?

options.label: A
options.text: Osteocalcin

options.label: B
options.text: Bone-Specific Alkaline Phosphatase (BSAP)

options.label: C
options.text: C-terminal propeptide of type I procollagen

options.label: D
options.text: Cathepsins K

questions.explanation:
Markers

Bone resorption

Bone formation
  • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase
  • Cathepsins K (Option D)
  • Collagen-related markers
  • Aminoterminal cross-linked telopeptide of type I collagen
  • Osteocalcin (Option A)
  • Bone-specific alkaline phosphatase (Option B)
  • C-terminal propeptide of type I procollagen (Option C)
